idioms.sense: to be very obvious or easy to predict
examples: Of course I'll help you. That goes without saying.

idioms.text: have something, nothing, etc. to say for yourself
idioms.sense: to be ready, unwilling, etc. to talk or give your views on something
examples: She doesn't have much to say for herself (= doesn't take part in conversation).
He had plenty to say for himself (= he had a lot of opinions and was willing to talk).
Late again—what have you got to say for yourself (= what is your excuse)?

idioms.text: have something to say (to somebody) about something
idioms.sense: to be angry
examples: He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it.

idioms.sense: used to introduce an opinion that makes what you have just said seem less strong
examples: I sometimes get worried in this job. Having said that, I enjoy doing it, it's a challenge.

idioms.text: I dare say (also I daresay especially in British English)
idioms.sense: used when you are saying that something is likely
examples: I dare say you know about it already.

idioms.text: if you don’t mind me/my saying so…
idioms.sense: used when you are going to criticize somebody or say something that might upset them
examples: That colour doesn't really suit you, if you don't mind my saying so.

idioms.sense: used to tell somebody that you have listened to their opinion, especially when you are going to express a different opinion
examples: I hear what you're saying, but you're wrong.

idioms.sense: used for emphasis to say ‘yes’
examples: ‘Does she see him often?’ ‘I'll say! Nearly every day.’

idioms.sense: used when you are commenting on a situation and saying that you are happy about it
examples: Most teachers, I'm glad to say, take their jobs very seriously.

idioms.sense: used for saying that something is disappointing
examples: He didn't accept the job, I'm sorry to say.

idioms.sense: used to emphasize an opinion
examples: Well, I must say, that's the funniest thing I've heard all week.

idioms.sense: used to express surprise, shock, etc.used to attract somebody’s attention or introduce a new subject of conversation
examples: I say! What a huge cake!
I say, can you lend me five pounds?

idioms.text: it says a lot, very little, etc. for somebody/something
idioms.sense: it shows a good/bad quality that somebody/something has
examples: It says a lot for her that she never lost her temper.
It didn't say much for their efficiency that the order arrived a week late.

idioms.sense: used to say that you would like something or to accept something that is offered
examples: I wouldn't say no to a pizza.
‘Tea, Brian?’ ‘I wouldn't say no.’

idioms.sense: a bad situation will pass or be forgotten most quickly if nothing more is said about it
the best thing to do is say as little as possible about something
used when commenting on a situation to suggest that you could say something more or worse but prefer not to
examples: Let's just say he wasn't very happy about the decision (= he was very unhappy or angry about it).

idioms.sense: used when making a suggestion or giving an example
examples: I can let you have it for, well let's say £100.

idioms.sense: used to emphasize what you are saying or to ask somebody if they really mean what they say
examples: I mean to say, you should have known how he would react!
Do you mean to say you've lost it?

idioms.sense: used to emphasize that the information you are giving is obvious
examples: The problem, needless to say, is the cost involved.

idioms.sense: do not stop hoping
used to say that something was, or will be, done immediately

idioms.text: not have a good word to say for somebody/something
idioms.sense: to never say anything good about somebody/something
examples: Nobody had a good word to say about him.

idioms.text: not say boo to a goose (British English) (North American English not say boo to anyone)
idioms.sense: to be very shy or gentle
examples: He's so nervous he wouldn't say boo to a goose.

idioms.sense: used to introduce a stronger way of describing something
examples: a difficult, not to say impossible, task

idioms.sense: used to ask somebody to smile before you take their photograph
to say something important
examples: You said a mouthful there, buddy.

idioms.sense: to refuse an offer, a suggestion, etc.
examples: If you don't invest in this, you're saying no to a potential fortune.

idioms.sense: used to say that you understand exactly what somebody means or is trying to say, so it is unnecessary to say anything more
examples: ‘They went to Paris together.’ ‘Say no more!’

idioms.sense: to say exactly what you feel or think
used to express surprise at what somebody has just said
examples: ‘He's getting married.’ ‘Say what?’

idioms.sense: used to ask somebody to tell you when you should stop pouring a drink or serving food for them because they have enough
to give an order; to make a request
examples: Just say the word, and I'll go.

idioms.sense: used to suggest that although you could say more, what you do say will be enough to explain what you mean
examples: I won’t go into all the details. Suffice it to say that the whole event was a complete disaster.

idioms.sense: in other words
examples: three days from now, that is to say on Friday

idioms.sense: used to introduce an opinion that makes what you have just said seem less strong
used to say that something is not very unusual or special
examples: She's a better player than me, but that's not saying much (= because I am a very bad player).

idioms.sense: used to say that it is impossible to predict what might happen
examples: There's no saying how he'll react.

idioms.text: there’s something, not much, etc. to be said for something/doing something
idioms.sense: there are/are not good reasons for doing something, believing something or agreeing with something
without making something seem better, worse, more serious, etc. than it really is
examples: I was surprised, to say the least.

idioms.sense: used to introduce a further fact or thing in addition to those already mentioned
examples: It was too expensive, to say nothing of the time it wasted.

idioms.sense: I agree completely
examples: ‘We must stand up for ourselves.’ ‘Well said, John.’

idioms.text: what do/would you say (to something/doing something)
idioms.sense: would you like something/to do something?
examples: What would you say to eating out tonight?
Let's go away for a weekend. What do you say?

idioms.sense: used to agree to somebody’s suggestion because you do not want to argue
a particular person must be obeyed
examples: Sarah wanted the kitchen painted green, and what she says, goes.

idioms.text: when all is said and done
idioms.sense: when everything is considered
examples: I know you're upset, but when all's said and done it isn't exactly a disaster.

idioms.sense: used to say that nobody knows the answer to a question
examples: Who can say what will happen next year?

idioms.sense: used to disagree with a statement or an opinion
examples: Who says I can't do it?

idioms.sense: used to say that something might happen or might have happened in a particular way, because nobody really knows
examples: Who's to say we would not have succeeded if we'd had more time?

idioms.sense: I agree with you completely
examples: ‘He's in a bad mood today.’ ‘You can say that again!’

idioms.sense: used to say that you think the offer you are making is reasonable or generous
examples: Look, I'll give you £100 for it. You can't say fairer than that.

idioms.sense: used to express surprise
examples: ‘They left without us.’ ‘You don't say!’ (= I'm not surprised)

idioms.sense: used to agree with somebody when they say something about themselves that you would not have been rude enough to say yourselfused to agree with somebody’s suggestion
examples: ‘I know I'm not the world's greatest cook.’ ‘You said it!’

senses.text: true or correct as a fact
examples: Did you get the answer right?
‘What's the right time?’ ‘10.37.’
That's exactly right.
‘David, isn't it?’ ‘Yes, that's right.’
(informal) It was Monday you went to see Angie, right?
Let me get this right (= understand correctly)—you want us to do an extra ten hours' work for no extra pay?
Are the following statements true or false?
Is it true (that) she’s leaving?
I got about half the answers right.
What’s the right time?
Only one of the answers is correct.
Check that all the details are correct.
I got about half the answers right.
There's something not quite right about these figures.
A few details are missing, but the description is more or less right.
right about something You were quite right about the weather.
right to do something They're absolutely right to be cautious.
‘It's not easy.’ ‘Yeah, you're right.’
right in doing something Am I right in thinking we've met before?
History has proved him right.
He never gets anything right.
I don't believe she's right in this case.
She was right about Tom having no money.
You're dead right. There's nothing we can do.

Next time we'll get it right.

right for somebody I'm glad you split up. She wasn't right for you.

I think we made the right decision.
You’re right to be cautious.
You made the right decision.
‘It’s not easy.’ ‘Yes, you’re right.’
What’s the correct way to shut the machine down?
I don’t think she’s correct to say he’s incompetent.
Is this the right way to the beach?
He's definitely the right person to ask.
I don't think she was right for you.
He's made the right decision.
Are you sure that sweater's on the right way (around)?

I'm sure it'll all turn out right in the end.
Customers have 30 days to decide if the finished product looks right with their decor.
Next time we'll get it exactly right.
I hope we're doing the right thing.
I don't know, it just doesn't seem right.
On some level this just feels right.
right to do something You were quite right to criticize him.
it's right to do something It's only right to warn you of the risk.
it's right that… It's right that he should be punished.
It may be a very easy way to make money, but that doesn't make it right.
James did what he thought was right.
Hunting may be legal, but that doesn't make it right.
I think you were right to do what you did.
I was doing what I thought was right.
You were quite right to tell me.
Is it ever right to kill?
I don't feel quite right today (= I feel ill).
Things aren't right between her parents.
If only I could have helped put matters right.
That sausage doesn't smell right.
The meat doesn't taste right to me.
We talk about the reasons why something doesn't look right.
(offensive) He's not quite right in the head (= not mentally normal).
She knows all the right people (= for example, people who can help her in her career).
They make sure that their children go to the right schools.
I wore the best clothes and was seen in all the right places.
If you know the right people, it opens more and more doors.
He is the consummate politician, a man who went to all the right schools and played by all the right rules.
your right hand/arm/foot/leg
My right eye is weaker than my left eye.
Keep on the right side of the road.
Take a right turn at the intersection.
You made a right mess of that!
I felt a right idiot.

idioms.text: be in the right place at the right time
idioms.sense: to be able to take advantage of opportunities when they come
examples: His success was down to being in the right place at the right time.

idioms.text: get/start off on the right/wrong foot (with somebody)
idioms.sense: to start a relationship well/badly
examples: I seem to have got off on the wrong foot with the new boss.

idioms.text: get on the right/wrong side of somebody
idioms.sense: to make somebody pleased with you/annoyed with you

idioms.text: give your right arm for something/to do something
idioms.sense: used to say that somebody is willing to give up a lot in order to have or do something that they really want
examples: I'd have given my right arm to have been there with them.

idioms.text: have your head screwed on (the right way)
idioms.sense: to be a sensible person
to have found a very good or successful way of living, doing something, etc.
examples: He's certainly got the right idea—retiring at 55.
The party had the right idea, but failed to win over the voters.

idioms.text: somebody’s heart is in the right place
idioms.sense: used to say that somebody’s intentions are kind and sincere even though they sometimes do the wrong thing
to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

idioms.sense: (not) mentally normal
examples: Who in their right mind would want to marry a murderer?
I thought I’d go mad if I stayed any longer.
A crazy old woman rented the upstairs room.
That noise is driving me nuts!
You guys are nuts!
Her mum’s completely batty.
She was out of her mind with grief.
No one in their right mind would choose to work there.

idioms.sense: having the power to do something gives you the right to do it
examples: Their foreign policy is based on the principle that ‘might is right’.

idioms.text: on the right/wrong side of 40, 50, etc.
idioms.sense: younger or older than 40, 50, etc. years of age
thinking or behaving in the right/wrong way
examples: We haven’t found a cure yet—but we are on the right track.
The new manager successfully got the team back onto the right track.
The police were on the wrong track when they treated the case as a revenge killing.

idioms.text: push all the (right) buttons (also press all the (right) buttons especially in British English)
idioms.sense: to do exactly the right things to please somebody
examples: a new satirical comedy show that pushes all the right buttons

idioms.sense: in excellent health or condition
certainly; in a way that cannot be denied
examples: You heard me right enough (= so don't pretend that you did not).

idioms.sense: used to express strong approval or support
with the top part turned to the top; in the correct, normal position
examples: I dropped my toast, but luckily it fell right side up.

idioms.sense: used to say that everything will be all right, even if there is a problem now
used to say that there is no doubt about something
examples: ‘We need to stick together.’ ‘Too right!’
‘I'll have to do it again.’ ‘Too right you will.’

senses.text: to move using your legs, going faster than when you walk
examples: Can you run as fast as Mike?
They turned and ran when they saw us coming.
She came running to meet us.
I had to run to catch the bus.
+ adv./prep. The dogs ran off as soon as we appeared.
He ran home in tears to his mother.
The children spent the morning running around in the park.
She can run really fast.
John can run very fast.
He ran out of the house.
She ran quickly downstairs.
She turned and ran blindly down the street.
Alan was running for a bus when he slipped on some ice.
Billy turned the corner and ran headlong into Mrs Bradley.
They've seen us! Run for your life!
The boy went running off to get the ball.
Who was the first person to run a mile in under four minutes?
I ran four miles today.
She used to run when she was at college.
I often go running before work.
Try to run round the block a few times every morning.
run in something He will be running in the 100 metres tonight.
There are only five horses running in the first race.
run something to run a marathon
Farah ran a fine race to take the gold medal.
The Derby will be run in spite of the bad weather.
I've spent the whole day running around after the kids.
to run a hotel/store/language school
He has no idea how to run a business.
Stop trying to run my life (= organize it) for me.
The shareholders want more say in how the company is run.
a badly run company
Both candidates have run a good campaign.
state-run industries
The school is jointly run with the local parish.

It is a small, privately run hotel.

The college runs several English classes for adults.

Volunteer counsellors run a 24-hour helpline.
Buses to Oxford run every half hour.
+ adv./prep. All the trains are running late (= are leaving later than planned).
Trains between London and Brighton run throughout the day.
Local buses run regularly to and from the school.
He claimed that 95 per cent of trains run on time.
When does the London Underground stop running at night?
run something + adv./prep. They run extra trains during the rush hour.
The transport company is concerned about the cost of running more buses.
Stan had the chainsaw running.
run on something Our van runs on (= uses) diesel.
run something Could you run the engine for a moment?
The engine was running very smoothly.
Our car only runs on unleaded petrol.

run something You can run the program overnight.
My PC runs Windows 10.
Don't forget to run a final spellcheck.

run something Run the tape, please.
run something + adv./prep. Can you run the tape back a few minutes?
I can't afford to run a car on my salary.
Shall I run you home?
Would you mind running me to the shops?

The sledge ran smoothly over the frozen snow.
The old tramlines are still there but now no trams run on them.
She ran her fingers nervously through her hair.
I ran my eyes over the page.
+ adv./prep. He had a scar running down his left cheek.
The road runs parallel to the river.
The railway line runs right past the house.
run something The bookcase runs the length of the room.
run something + adv./prep. We ran a cable from the lights to the stage.
The tears ran down her cheeks.
Water was running all over the bathroom floor.
run something (into something) She ran hot water into the bucket.
to run the hot tap (= to turn it so that water flows from it)
run something for somebody I'll run a bath for you.
run somebody something I'll run you a bath.

Your nose is running (= mucus is flowing from it).

+ adv./prep. Programmes are running a few minutes behind schedule this evening.

run for somebody/something Hilary Clinton ran for president in 2016.

idioms.sense: to be pleased to do what somebody wants
examples: She knew she had only to call and he would come running.

idioms.sense: to run in order to escape from somebody/something

idioms.text: run roughshod over somebody (US English usually) (especially British English ride, etc. roughshod over somebody)
idioms.sense: to treat somebody badly and not worry about their feelings
working fully and correctly
examples: It will be a lot easier when we have the database up and running.
